docs.snippet: One-hundred-degree heat and melting humidity suddenly didn't seem so bad when, on my very first cast into the waters of the Amazon Basin, something left a swirl the size of a bathtub behind my surface lure.    ''Probably a piraracu,'' said Eduardo...
docs.lead_paragraph: One-hundred-degree heat and melting humidity suddenly didn't seem so bad when, on my very first cast into the waters of the Amazon Basin, something left a swirl the size of a bathtub behind my surface lure. ''Probably a piraracu,'' said Eduardo von Muhlen, who seemed unfazed as he held our tippy wooden canoe in position with his paddle.
docs.abstract: Stephen C Sautner Outdoors column on fishing in Mamiraua Sustainable Development Reserve in northwestern Brazil (M)

headline.main: Casting, Catching, Eating In the Heat

docs.snippet: Bowfinger      Unable to afford the action star Kit Ramsey (Eddie Murphy), the hard-pressed but indefatigable movie producer Bobby Bowfinger (Steve Martin, left) plans to trail Ramsey around town with a camera and have actors Bobby  can afford (me...
docs.lead_paragraph: Bowfinger Unable to afford the action star Kit Ramsey (Eddie Murphy), the hard-pressed but indefatigable movie producer Bobby Bowfinger (Steve Martin, left) plans to trail Ramsey around town with a camera and have actors Bobby can afford (meaning they work on spec) accost Ramsey at the deli or wherever and film whatever transpires for Bobby's space flick, ''Chubby Rain.'' Eventually, though, Bobby must turn to a Ramsey look-alike named Jiff (also Mr. Murphy). Jiff is pretty good, too, Janet Maslin wrote in The New York Times, as is Frank Oz's ''Bowfinger,'' which is ''smoothly directed and acted with glee.''
docs.abstract: Brief reviews of films now released on video: Bowfinger, Twin Falls Idaho, The 13th Warrior and An Ideal Husband; photo

docs.snippet: WHICH was tougher: prying three American soldiers from the grasp of Slobodan Milosevic, or trying to liberate a 6-year-old Cuban boy from bureaucratic bumbling, juridical hocus-pocus and political pandering in America?    No contest, said the Rev....
docs.lead_paragraph: WHICH was tougher: prying three American soldiers from the grasp of Slobodan Milosevic, or trying to liberate a 6-year-old Cuban boy from bureaucratic bumbling, juridical hocus-pocus and political pandering in America? No contest, said the Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, until two weeks ago the general secretary of the National Council of Churches in New York. ''Getting the soldiers out of Serbia wasn't easy, but it was easier,'' she said. ''As complicated as that was, the emotions vested in the Cuban-Americans in Miami and the political weight that they have -- that's the wild card in this.''
docs.abstract: Clyde Haberman, in NYC column, holds that Elian Gonzalez, 6-year-old boy who survived escape from Cuba that drowned his mother, carries four decades of miserable US-Cuban relations on his tiny shoulders; cites contention of Rev Joan Brown Campbell, former general secretary of National Council of Churches, that had he come from any other country, he would have been sent home to his father weeks ago, instead of remaining in Miami with relatives and other Cuban-Americans out to make anti-Castro poster boy of him (M)

headline.main: A Tug of War As Complex As War

docs.snippet: A Brief Life, Burning Bright      In the original stage adaptation of Anne Frank's diary, there is never any mystery surrounding her fate. Even children who do not know her story will recognize the note of loss in the first scene, when Otto Frank ...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Brief Life, Burning Bright In the original stage adaptation of Anne Frank's diary, there is never any mystery surrounding her fate. Even children who do not know her story will recognize the note of loss in the first scene, when Otto Frank returns to the Amsterdam hideaway and retrieves his daughter's journal.
docs.abstract: Family Fare column suggests happenings of interest to families in New York this weekend; photo (S)

docs.snippet: BASEBALL    American League  KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Agreed to terms with C Jorge Fabregas on a minor league contract.  TEXAS RANGERS -- Agreed to terms with LHP Darren Oliver on a three-year contract. Designated OF Scarborough Green for reassignmen...
docs.lead_paragraph: BASEBALL American League KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Agreed to terms with C Jorge Fabregas on a minor league contract. TEXAS RANGERS -- Agreed to terms with LHP Darren Oliver on a three-year contract. Designated OF Scarborough Green for reassignment. National League ATLANTA BRAVES -- Agreed to terms with RHP Rudy Seanez on a one-year contract. Sold the contract of INF Howard Battle to Hanshin of the Japanese Central League. LOS ANGELES DODGERS -- Signed OF Todd Hollandsworth to a one-year contract. MILWAUKEE BREWERS -- Acquired RHP Jaime Navarro and RHP John Snyder from the Chicago White Sox for RHP Cal Eldred and INF Jose Valentin.

docs.snippet: Joe Roth, who has been in charge of Walt Disney Motion Pictures since 1994 and chairman of Walt Disney Studios since 1996, said today that he was leaving Disney to form his own mini-studio, a company that will both make and distribute movies. He i...
docs.lead_paragraph: Joe Roth, who has been in charge of Walt Disney Motion Pictures since 1994 and chairman of Walt Disney Studios since 1996, said today that he was leaving Disney to form his own mini-studio, a company that will both make and distribute movies. He is being replaced by Peter Schneider, his second-in-command and the longtime head of the lucrative animation division. ''It's a great time to be out forming a new company,'' Mr. Roth said. ''As someone who has supervised over 250 movies over the last 15 years, I felt I would be happier cobbling together my own company, which simply made movies, without the infrastructure and cost and overhead that any big studio carries with it.''
docs.abstract: Joe Roth, who has been in charge of Walt Disney Motion Pictures since 1994 and chairman of Walt Disney Studios since 1996, is leaving Disney to form his own mini-studio; he is being replaced by Peter Schneider, his second-in-command and longtime head of lucrative animation division; photo (M)

headline.main: Disney Studio Chairman Decides to Step Down

docs.snippet: Does this story sound familiar? A young man borrows money from friends and family to start a company that he contends will revolutionize the world and end information overload for the majority of Americans. After some lean years, he becomes one of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Does this story sound familiar? A young man borrows money from friends and family to start a company that he contends will revolutionize the world and end information overload for the majority of Americans. After some lean years, he becomes one of the richest and most powerful men in the world, and his company dominates its field. No, this is not the story of William H. Gates of Microsoft, or even Stephen M. Case at America Online. The hero of this tale is Henry R. Luce, who with Briton Hadden founded Time Inc. in the early 1920's. Since then, Time has been in the forefront of almost every technological change in what is now called the media business, but back then was known as newspapering.
docs.abstract: History of Time Warner Inc in light of America Online Inc's acquisition of company; notes company was founded in 1923 when Henry R Luce and Briton Hadden, with borrowed $86,375, introduced Time magazine; chart on major events in company history, 1923-2000; photos (M)

docs.snippet: ''Being John Malkovich,'' the quirky comedy directed by Spike Jonze, and ''Topsy-Turvy,'' Mike Leigh's loving 19th-century backstage drama, shared the award for best picture handed out on Saturday by the National Society of Film Critics. It was th...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Being John Malkovich,'' the quirky comedy directed by Spike Jonze, and ''Topsy-Turvy,'' Mike Leigh's loving 19th-century backstage drama, shared the award for best picture handed out on Saturday by the National Society of Film Critics. It was the first time in the society's 34 years that two films had tied for the award, reflecting what voters felt was an unusually strong field. The society, made up of 53 critics from New York, Los Angeles and other cities, had less of a struggle voting for a best director, giving the prize to Mr. Leigh. David O. Russell took second place for his work on ''Three Kings,'' a dark comedy about three soldiers during the final days of the gulf war. Sam Mendes, a first-time director whose ''American Beauty'' is considered a strong Oscar contender, placed third, though the film's cinematographer, Conrad L. Hall, won the society's top prize for his lush, rose-dappled visuals.

docs.snippet: For years, Harold O. Levy, a corporate lawyer with a seat on the State Board of Regents, has regularly shared his thoughts on education, sometimes on a daily basis, with a who's who of New York City's civic, education and business leaders.     The...
docs.lead_paragraph: For years, Harold O. Levy, a corporate lawyer with a seat on the State Board of Regents, has regularly shared his thoughts on education, sometimes on a daily basis, with a who's who of New York City's civic, education and business leaders. The leaders, whom he contacts by fax or with quick, breezy calls from his cell phone, are less public figures than consummate insiders, much like Mr. Levy himself. And they have grown fondly accustomed to being his sounding boards for a wide range of ideas, like his drive to eliminate coal-burning furnaces in school buildings and to increase the city's share of state money for schools.

headline.main: Man in the News; Executive With a Passion for Ideas: Harold Oscar Levy

docs.snippet: TO the untrained observer, Swedes and Norwegians (a.k.a. the Olsons and the Olsens) may seem interchangeable. Both are prosperous, blue-eyed and reserved. On the world stage, they hand out peace prizes and preach global cooperation while saving th...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO the untrained observer, Swedes and Norwegians (a.k.a. the Olsons and the Olsens) may seem interchangeable. Both are prosperous, blue-eyed and reserved. On the world stage, they hand out peace prizes and preach global cooperation while saving their aggressions, if any, for the ski slope. However, in the privacy of their snowbound peninsula, Sweden and Norway have lately resembled ''two blind men slugging it out on a highway,'' in the words of a Danish commentator.
docs.abstract: Unraveling of $50 billion merger between Swedish and Norwegian state-owned telecommunications companies exposes dark current of national chauvinism and aggression 94 years after Norway achieved its independence; drawing (M)
